translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The Discussion with Māgha
Thus have I heard:

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate
translated: At one time the Blessed One was staying at Rājagaha on the Vulture Peak Mountain.

original: Atha kho māgho māṇavo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodi.
analyzed: atha khalu māghaḥ māṇavaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhim sammodi
translated: Then the brahmin student Māgha went to the Blessed One and exchanged greetings with him.

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi
translated: When this courteous and amiable talk was finished, he sat down at one side

original: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho māgho māṇavo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: eka mantam nisinnaḥ khalu māghaḥ māṇavaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: and said to the Blessed One:

original: “Ahañhi, bho gotama, dāyako dānapati vadaññū yācayogo;
analyzed: aham hi bho gotama dāyakaḥ dānapati vadaññū yāca yogaḥ
translated: “Master Gotama, I am a giver, a munificent donor, one who gives the alms-food that is my food.
I seek wealth righteously,

original: dhammena bhoge pariyesitvā dhammaladdhehi bhogehi dhammādhigatehi ekassapi dadāmi🔽dvinnampi tiṇṇampi catunnampi pañcannampi channampi sattannampi aṭṭhannampi navannampi
analyzed: dhammena bhoge pariyesitvā dhamma laddhehi bhogehi dhamma adhigatehi ekassa api dadāmi  dvinnam pi tiṇṇam pi catunnam pi pañcannam pi channam pi sattannam pi aṭṭhannam pi navannam pi
translated: and having sought it righteously, I give righteously.🔽I give to one, to two, to three, to four, to five, to ten, to twenty, to thirty, to forty, to fifty, to a hundred, to a thousand,

original: dasannampi dadāmi, vīsāyapi tiṁsāyapi cattālīsāyapi paññāsāyapi dadāmi, satassapi🔽dadāmi, bhiyyopi dadāmi.
analyzed: dadāmi tisāya pi cattālīsāya api paññāsāya pi dadāmi satassa pi 🔽dadāmi bhiyyaḥ api dadāmi
translated: to a hundred thousand.

original: Kaccāhaṁ, bho gotama, evaṁ dadanto evaṁ yajanto bahuṁ puññaṁ pasavāmī”ti?
analyzed: kacca āha bho gotamaḥ evam dadantaḥ evam yajantaḥ bahum puññam pasavāmi iti
translated: Do I generate much merit by giving in this way and sacrificing in this way?”

original: “Taggha tvaṁ, māṇava, evaṁ dadanto evaṁ yajanto bahuṁ puññaṁ pasavasi.
analyzed: tat ha tva māṇavaḥ evam dadantaḥ evam yajantaḥ bahum puññam pasavasi
translated: “Yes, student, you do generate much merit by giving in this way and sacrificing in this way.

original: Yo kho, māṇava, dāyako dānapati vadaññū yācayogo;
analyzed: yaḥ kho māṇava dāyakaḥ dānapati vadaññū yāca yogaḥ
translated: “The one who gives a gift,
who seeks wealth righteously,🔽and then gives a gift—🔽whether to one person or to a hundred—

original: dhammena bhoge pariyesitvā dhammaladdhehi bhogehi dhammādhigatehi ekassapi dadāti …pe… satassapi dadāti, bhiyyopi dadāti, bahuṁ so puññaṁ pasavatī”ti.
analyzed: dhammena bhoge pariyesitvā dhamma laddhehi bhogehi dhamma adhigatehi ekassa api dadāti pe satassa api dadāti bhiyyas api dadāti bahum so puññam pasavati iti
translated: generates much merit.”

original: Atha kho māgho māṇavo bhagavantaṁ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi—
analyzed: atha khalu māghaḥ māṇavaḥ bhagavantam gāthāya ajjhabhāsi
translated: Then Māgha recited this verse in the presence of the Buddha:
“I ask the one who gives,

analyzed: iti māghaḥ māṇavaḥ  kāsāyavāsim agaham caranta
translated: (so says Māgha)🔽the one who wears the ochre robe, the one who goes forth without taking anything,

analyzed: yaḥ yāca yogaḥ dāna pati gahaṭṭhaḥ
translated: the one who seeks, the one who gives, the one who sacrifices, the one who lives at home,
the one who seeks merit, the one who looks to merit,
the one who gives food and drink to others here—
how is the sacrifice of the one who sacrifices purified?”

analyzed: yaḥ yāca yogaḥ dāna pati gahaṭṭhaḥ
translated: “The one who seeks, the one who gives, the one who sacrifices, the one who lives at home,
(so said the Buddha to Māgha)
One who desires merit, who seeks merit,
By giving food and drink to others here,
One should worship those worthy of gifts.”

analyzed: yaḥ yāca yogaḥ dāna pati gahaṭṭhaḥ
translated: “One who is a householder, a giver, a lord of giving,

analyzed: iti māghaḥ māṇavaḥ  puññatthikaḥ yajati puññapekkhaḥ
translated: (Thus said the Magadhan youth)🔽One who desires merit, who seeks merit,
By giving food and drink to others here,
Please tell me, Blessed One, who is worthy of gifts.”
“Those who wander in the world without attachment,
Possessing nothing, perfected, restrained,
At the right time one should offer oblations to them,
If a brahmin desires merit and should sacrifice.
Those who have cut all bonds and ties,
Tamed, liberated, free from distress and desire;
At the right time one should offer oblations to them,
If a brahmin desires merit and should sacrifice.
Those who are completely liberated from all bonds,
Tamed, liberated, free from distress and desire;
At the right time one should offer oblations to them,
If a brahmin desires merit and should sacrifice.
Having abandoned passion, hatred, and delusion,
Their taints destroyed, having lived the spiritual life,
At the right time one should offer oblations to them,
The brahmin who seeks merit should sacrifice to them.

original: Yesu na māyā vasati na māno,
analyzed: yesu na māyā vasati na māno
translated: Those in whom deceit and conceit do not exist,
who are free from defilements, who have lived the spiritual life,
at the right time one should offer sacrifice to them,

original: Yo brāhmaṇo puññapekkho yajetha.🔽Ye vītalobhā amamā nirāsā,
analyzed: yaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ puññapekkhaḥ yajetha  ye vīta lobhāḥ amamāḥ
translated: the brahmin who seeks merit should sacrifice to them.🔽Those who are free from greed, who are without possessions, who are free from longing,
who are free from defilements, who have lived the spiritual life,
at the right time one should offer sacrifice to them,

original: Yo brāhmaṇo puññapekkho yajetha.🔽Ye ve na taṇhāsu upātipannā,
analyzed: yaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ puññapekkhaḥ yajetha  ye ve na taṇhāsu upātipannā
translated: the brahmin who seeks merit should sacrifice to them.🔽Those who are not subject to craving,
who have crossed over the flood, who wander without possessions,
at the right time one should offer sacrifice to them,
the brahmin who seeks merit should sacrifice to them.

analyzed: yesam taṇhā na atthi kuhiñci loke
translated: Those who have no craving anywhere in the world,
for existence or non-existence here or beyond,
at the right time one should offer sacrifice to them,
the brahmin who seeks merit should sacrifice to them.
Those who have abandoned sense pleasures, who wander without attachment,

analyzed: su sañña tat tā tasaravaḥ ujju
translated: like a straight arrow well-aimed,
at the right time one should offer sacrifice to them,
the brahmin who seeks merit should sacrifice to them.

analyzed: ye vīta rāgā su samāhita indriyā
translated: Those who are free from passion, whose faculties are well-concentrated,
Like the moon freed from an eclipse,
At the right time, one should offer a sacrifice to them,
If one is a brahmin who desires merit and makes offerings.
Those who are skilled in the chants, free from passion and anger,
Whose destination is not known here, having abandoned it;
At the right time, one should offer a sacrifice to them,
If one is a brahmin who desires merit and makes offerings.
Having abandoned birth and death entirely,
Having gone beyond all doubt and uncertainty;
At the right time, one should offer a sacrifice to them,
If one is a brahmin who desires merit and makes offerings.
Those who wander in the world as their own light,
Possessing nothing, completely free everywhere;
At the right time, one should offer a sacrifice to them,
If one is a brahmin who desires merit and makes offerings.

original: Ye hettha jānanti yathā tathā idaṁ,
analyzed: ye ha itthā jānanti yathā tathā idam
translated: Those who know here what is so and what is not so,

analyzed: ayam antimā na atthi punabbhavaḥ ti
translated: That this is the end, there is no more becoming;
At the right time, one should offer a sacrifice to them,
If one is a brahmin who desires merit and makes offerings.
One who is a knower of the Vedas, delighting in jhana, mindful,
Who has attained enlightenment and is a refuge for many;
At the right time, one should offer a sacrifice to them,
The brahmin who is desirous of merit should sacrifice.”
“Surely my question was not in vain,
(so said the Magadhan youth)
The Fortunate One has explained to me the worthy one;

analyzed: tvañc ha itthā jānāsi yathā tathā ida
translated: You know here what is so and what is not so,

original: Tathā hi te vidito esa dhammo.
analyzed: tathā hi te viditaḥ esa dhammo
translated: For this is a Dhamma that is known to you.

analyzed: yaḥ yāca yogaḥ dāna pati gahaṭṭhaḥ
translated: The householder who is a seeker of alms, a giver, a lord of giving,
Who sacrifices for the sake of merit, desirous of merit;
Giving food and drink here to others,
Please explain to me the sacrifice that is complete.”
“Sacrifice, O sacrificer,
(said the Fortunate One)
And be full of confidence in all things;
The sacrifice of the sacrificer is the object,
Having established oneself here one abandons hatred.

original: So vītarāgo pavineyya dosaṁ,🔽Mettaṁ cittaṁ bhāvayamappamāṇaṁ;
analyzed: saḥ vīta rāgaḥ dosa  mettam cittam bhāvayam appamāṇa
translated: Free from passion he should drive out hatred,🔽And develop a limitless mind of loving-kindness;
Day and night always being heedful,
He should radiate limitless loving-kindness in all directions.”
“Who is purified, who is liberated, who is bound?
By what name does one go to the Brahma world?

analyzed: a jānataḥ me muni brūhi puṭṭhaḥ
translated: Please explain to me, O Sage, who is ignorant, when asked,

analyzed: bhagavā hi me sakkhi brahmajja diṭṭhaḥ
translated: The Blessed One is my witness, having seen the brahma-world.

analyzed: tuvan hi naḥ brahma samaḥ asi sat ca
translated: You are truly like a Brahmā to us,
How does one go to the Brahmā-world with radiance?”
“One who sacrifices the threefold sacrifice in abundance,
(the Blessed One said)🔽Having served those worthy of gifts,
Having sacrificed rightly, with a mind of generosity,

analyzed: upapajjati brahma lokan ti brūmi iti
translated: One goes to the Brahmā-world, I say.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, māgho māṇavo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte māghaḥ māṇavaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, the student Māgha said this to the Blessed One:
“Magnificent, Master Gotama …
From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
The Discourse with Māgha is the fifth.
